title: Incitec Pivot CEO warns of $38b in destruction
text:
"If we continue our current trajectory, we will simply kill off domestic gas demand, resulting in businesses destroyed and jobs heading overseas,'' Ms Johns said.

Ms Johns also borrowed a phrase regularly used by Prime Minister Scott Morrison, declaring gas policy should take into account the fate of "quiet Australians''.

"For the quiet Australians working in highly skilled manufacturing jobs in places like Mt Isa, Townsville, Moranbah and other urban centres, the time for them to act is now,'' she said.

The market on the east coast of Australia had been distorted by the LNG export industry after three LNG plants near Gladstone in Queensland were established in late 2015.

About $80 billion was ploughed into the three plants, one of which is run by Santos. Ms Johns said they had since captured 70 per cent of gas supply, and exported it to offshore customers.

"This has triggered a dysfunctional domestic gas market and a tripling of gas prices in the east coast,'' she said.

Ms Johns said gas-based manufacturing contributed $38 billion to Australia's gross domestic product. The ''wealth transfer'' to gas exporters had already been about $1 billion.

Australian Energy Market Operator figures showed demand for domestic industrial gas in the last five years had decreased by about 15 per cent, she said.

Advertisement

"This is industrial demand destruction and jobs,'' Ms Johns said.

She said gas and energy prices were much lower in the United States and that was why Australian companies including steelmaker BlueScope were making big investments in the US, like the $1 billion-plus expansion of the North Star steel mill in Ohio.

She also cited the closure of RemaPak, a 40-year-old family-owned manufacturing business in Sydney which went into administration in January after its energy costs ''skyrocketed'' more than fourfold in three years, leaving it unable to compete against importers.

She said that in May, high gas prices contributed to Dow Chemical’s decision to close a plant in Melbourne.

Three-pronged fix

Ms Johns proposed a three-pronged solution to fix the gas market.

She said the first step was ''the need for a trigger'' on the Australian Domestic Gas Security Mechanism. "Australian users shouldn’t be subsidising LNG exporters building and operating their facilities,'' she said.

She said a ''fair price is LNG net back – minus invested capital and costs''.

Advertisement

The second plank was a domestic gas reservation policy with a ''use it or lose it'' mechanism.

The third element was to ensure that both small and large gas users had ''fair and equitable'' access to pipeline transportation.

Stephen Bell, the chief executive of plastics maker Qenos, told the Summit that it seemed absurd for Australia to be talking about LNG import terminals when those boats carrying LNG were sailing past LNG export vessels from Australia.

"It's strategically stupid,'' Mr Bell said.

Garbis Simonian, the managing director of Weston Aluminium, said it would make sense for the Narrabri gas project of Santos to get up and running quickly because it was relatively close to major population centres of Newcastle and Sydney.

"The advantage of Narrabri is it's close to markets,'' he said.
description: Jeanne Johns says the gas market is "dysfunctional" and a use-it-or-lose it policy is needed to stop gas companies banking future supply for LNG plants.
